examples.translation: He wrote a long letter.
They wrote interesting books.

katav.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root כ.ת.ב is associated with writing and lettering.

idioms.usage: הַכְּתַב יָד שֶׁלּוֹ קָשֶׁה לְהַבָּנָה.
כּוֹתֵב הַסֵּפֶר מוּכָּר בְּכָל הָעוֹלָם.

examples.translation: I learned Hebrew at the university.
The children are learning at school.

lamad.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ל.מ.ד is associated with learning and education.

idioms.usage: אֲנַחְנוּ צְרִיכִים לִלְמוֹד בְּכָל רֶגַע.

idioms.translation: there is no end to learning
idioms.usage: כְּמוֹ שֶׁאוֹמְרִים, אֵין סוֹף לְלִמּוּד.

meaning: to pretend to be a student
[archaic or poetic] to cause to learn

examples.translation: She is reading a new book.
We read the message.

kara.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ק.ר.א relates to reading and calling. Note that 'קָרָא' can also mean 'he called'. Context determines the meaning.

idioms.usage: המורה ביקש מהתלמידים לקרוא בקול רם.
היושב ראש קרא לסדר בישיבה.

examples.translation: We are talking about the plan.
He spoke about the project's details.

diber.notes: Regular verb in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל). The root ד.ב.ר is associated with speech and communication.

idioms.usage: הוא דִּבֵּר בִּגְלוּיִים עַל הַקָּשָׁיִים.
היא דִּבְּרָה בְּשֵׁם הַצֶּוֶת.

examples.translation: She sang a beautiful song.
We will sing at the party tomorrow.

shir.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ש.י.ר is associated with singing and songs.

idioms.usage: הם שָׁרוּ שִׁיר הַלֵּל בְּבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת.
הַשִּׁיר הַזֶּה נוֹתֵן לִי כֹּחַ בְּזְמַן קָשֶׁה.

hifil.note: Note: Different meaning, same spelling but different root ש-י-ר

shamar.root_meaning: Related to guarding, keeping, or preserving

examples.translation: He kept the secret.
We are maintaining order.

shamar.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ש.מ.ר is associated with guarding, keeping, and preserving.

idioms.usage: בְּתֹם הַוִּכּוּחַ, הוּא שָׁמַר מֶרְחָק.
הוּא אִישׁ דָּתִי וְשׁוֹמֵר מִצְווֹת.

examples.translation: The children run in the park every morning.
She ran quickly to the airplane.

ratz.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ר.ו.צ is associated with running and rushing. Note the vowel changes and the presence of י during conjugation.

idioms.translation: spread quickly ('ran like fire in the field')
idioms.usage: הַשְּׁמוּעָה רָצְתָה כְּאֵשׁ בַּשָּׂדֶה.

idioms.translation: to go over songs quickly (to skim)
idioms.usage: הַמְנַצֵּחַ בִּיקֵּשׁ מֵהַמְּשׂוֹרֵר לָרוּץ עַל הַזִּמְרוֹת.

avad.root_meaning: Related to work, labor, or service

examples.translation: We are working together on the project.
He worked at a big company.

avad.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ע.ב.ד is associated with work, labor, and service.

idioms.usage: הנַגָּר עָבַד בְּיָדָיו לִיצוֹר אֶת הַשֻּׁלְחָן.
היא עוֹבֶדֶת שָׁעוֹת נוֹסָפוֹת בְּשָׁבוּעַ הַזֶּה.

examples.translation: The children are playing in the yard.
He acted in the new movie.

sichek.notes: Regular verb in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל). The root ש.ח.ק is associated with playing, acting, and joking.

idioms.usage: היא שִׂחֲקָה אֶת הַתַּפְקִיד בִּצּוּרָה מְעוּלָה.
כֻּלָּנוּ מְשַׂחֲקִים בְּמִשְׂחַק הַחַיִּים.

examples.translation: She laughed at the joke.
We are laughing together.

tzachak.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root צ.ח.ק is associated with laughter and joy.
related_words: צַחְקָן (joker, someone who laughs a lot)

idioms.usage: הבדיחה הייתה כל כך מצחיקה שְׁצָחַקְנוּ עַד דְּמָעוֹת.
צְחוֹק הַגּוֹרָל, הִיא נִפְגְּשָׁה אִתּוֹ שׁוּב.

examples.translation: He drank a glass of water.
We drink coffee in the morning.

shata.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ש.ת.ה is associated with drinking. Note the changes in the root letters during conjugation.

idioms.translation: drank the cup to the bottom (drained the cup)
idioms.usage: הוא שָׁתָה אֶת הַכּוֹס עַד הַתַּחְתִּית במסיבה.
בְּקַיִץ, הַיֶּלֶד שׁוֹתֶה כַּמַּיִם.

nifal.note: Forms in Nif'al are not commonly used for this root.

piel.note: Forms in Pi'el are not used for this root.

pual.note: Forms in Pu'al are not used for this root.

hitpael.note: Forms in Hitpa'el are not used for this root.

examples.translation: She saw an excellent movie.
Do you see the stars?

ra'ah.notes: The verb 'לִרְאוֹת' is irregular in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ר-א-ה involves weak letters, resulting in irregular conjugations, especially in the imperative and future tenses.

idioms.usage: לאחר שנים, הוא רָאָה אוֹר והבין את הטעות.

idioms.translation: only to look, not to touch
idioms.usage: הפָּסֶל זֶה לִרְאוֹת וְלֹא לִגְּעֹת.

nifal.note: Irregular forms due to weak root.

piel.note: Forms in Pi'el are not commonly used for this root.

pual.note: Forms in Pu'al are not commonly used for this root.

hitpael.note: Commonly used in the expression 'להתראות' (see you).

paal.root_meaning: Related to action, doing, or operation

examples.translation: He acted during the crisis.
We are acting for the environment.

paal.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root פ.ע.ל is central in Hebrew and is associated with action and work. Interestingly, 'פָּעַל' is also the name of this verb pattern (binyan).

idioms.usage: היא פָּעֲלָה לְטוֹבַת הַקְּהִלָּה.
הוא פָּעַל בֵּינוֹ לְבֵין עַצְמוֹ בְּנֹשֵׂא זֶה.

examples.translation: We are eating a meal together.
He ate at the new restaurant.

achal.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root א.כ.ל is associated with eating and consumption. Note that in some forms, the initial א is silent in pronunciation.

idioms.translation: you messed up (literally: you ate her)
idioms.usage: אם לא תשקיע, אֲכַלְתָּ אוֹתָהּ במבחן.
ההרצאה הייתה אֹכֶל לְמַחְשָׁבָה.

nifal.note: Forms in Nif'al are not commonly used for this root.

piel.note: Forms in Pi'el are not commonly used for this root.

hitpael.note: Forms in Hitpa'el are not commonly used for this root.

examples.translation: I am going to the store.
She went to visit her grandmother.

halach.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ה.ל.ך involves a third-letter weak root (the letter ך), resulting in irregular conjugations, especially in the future and imperative tenses.

idioms.usage: הפרויקט הוֹלֵךְ וּמִתְפַּתֵּחַ בצורה יפה.

idioms.translation: walked on the thin line (took a risk)
idioms.usage: הוא הָלַךְ עַל הַקָּוֵּה הַדָּק בהחלטתו.

nifal.note: Forms in Nif'al are not commonly used for this root.

pual.note: Forms in Pu'al are not used for this root.

examples.translation: I know the answer.
She knew the secret.

yada.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root י.ד.ע involves weak letters, resulting in some irregular conjugations, especially in the imperative and future tenses.

idioms.usage: הפילוסוף יָדַע שֶׁאֵין לוֹ יְדִיעָה מֻחְלֶטֶת.
מִי יוֹדֵעַ מָתַי נִפְגּוֹשׁ שׁוּב.

nifal.note: Rarely used.

examples.translation: I understand the situation.
She didn't understand the question.

hevin.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל). The root ב.י.ן is associated with understanding and comprehension. 'לְהָבִין' is in the Hif'il binyan, which often indicates causative action.

idioms.usage: סליחה, אֵין לִי מֻשָּׂג מה התשובה.
החוֹקֵר הֵבִין דָּבָר מִתּוֹךְ דָּבָר.

examples.translation: She said that she will come.
What do you say?

amar.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root א.מ.ר is associated with saying and speech. Note the irregular infinitive 'לוֹמַר'.

idioms.translation: say and do (follow words with actions)
idioms.usage: צריך אֱמֹר וְעֲשֵׂה, לא רק לדבר.

idioms.translation: whatever is said to you, do (be obedient)
idioms.usage: הוא למד שׁכָּל הָאֹמֵר לוֹ עֲשֵׂה.

nifal.note: Forms in Nif'al are not commonly used for this root.

pual.note: Forms in Pu'al are not commonly used for this root.

hitpael.note: Forms in Hitpa'el are not commonly used for this root.

examples.translation: Will you come to the party?
They came from distant places.

ba.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ב.ו.א is associated with coming and arriving. Note the irregular forms due to the presence of weak letters.

idioms.usage: סֵפֶר מְעַנְיֵן בָּא לְיָדַי.
הכַּעַס שֶׁלּוֹ בָּא לְבִיטּוּי בְּדִבּוּרָיו.

examples.translation: I think that it's a good idea.
She thought about the proposal.

chashav.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ח.ש.ב is associated with thinking and calculation. This root is also used in words related to computers (מַחְשֵׁב).

idioms.translation: thought carefully before acting (literally: counted to three)
idioms.usage: תמיד חָשַׁב עַד שְׁלוֹשָׁה לפני שהחליט.
כְּדַאי לְךָ לַחֲשֹׁב פַּעֲמַיִם לפני שאתה פועל.

examples.translation: She loves chocolate.
They loved hiking in nature.

ahav.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root א.ה.ב is associated with love and affection. Note that in pronunciation, the initial א is often silent.

idioms.usage: זֶה הָיָה אַהֲבָה מִמַּבָּט רִאשׁוֹן.
הִיא אוֹהֶבֶת אֶת בְּנָהּ כָּמוֹתוֹ.

nifal.note: Forms in Nif'al are rarely used for this root.

examples.translation: I want to go to the movie.
What do you want to eat?

ratzah.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ר.צ.ה is associated with wanting and desiring. Note the changes in vowels in different conjugations due to the weak letter ה at the end of the root.

idioms.usage: כִּרְצוֹנְךָ, אֲנִי מוּכָן לְעֲזֹר.
הוא רָצָה בְּרָצוֹן לְהִתְנַדֵּב.

examples.translation: She gave him a beautiful gift.
It is possible to give help to the team.

natan.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root נ.ת.ן is associated with giving and providing. Note the irregular forms in the future and imperative due to the root letters.

idioms.usage: המנהל נָתַן חוֹפְשִׁי לַצָּוֶת לְיָצֵר.
תֵּן לִי יוֹם לַחְשֹׁב עַל זֶּה.

examples.translation: I meet my friends at the café.
She met him on the street.

pagash.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root פ.ג.שׁ is associated with meeting or encountering.

idioms.usage: הם פָּגְשׁוּ פָּנִים אֶל פָּנִים לְרִאשׁוֹנָה.
הוא פָּגַשׁ אוֹתָהּ בְּמִקְרֶה בְּסוּפֶּר.

nifal.note: Commonly used for mutual meetings.

examples.translation: The child slept all night.
We sleep in a tent in nature.

yashan.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root י.ש.נ involves weak letters, resulting in irregular forms, especially in the future and imperative. The verb 'לִישׁוֹן' is commonly used to express sleeping.
related_words: יָשָׁן (old; different meaning when used as an adjective)

idioms.usage: המשקיע יָשֵׁן עַל זְהָב.
מַגִּיעַ הַזְּמַן לָלֶכֶת לִישׁוֹן.

examples.translation: He succeeded in achieving the goal.
I hope that you succeed in the exam.

hitzliach.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which is often used for causative actions. The root צ.ל.ח relates to success and prosperity. 'להצליח' means 'to succeed' or 'to cause to succeed'.

idioms.usage: בְּהַצְלָחָה בַּמִּשְׂחָק!
הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט הַזֶּה הִצְלִיחַ לְמַעְלָה מִן הַמְּצֻפֶּה.

nifal.note: Rare usage.

examples.translation: I use the computer for work.
They used the map to navigate the city.

hishtamesh.notes: This verb is in binyan Hitpael (הִתְפַּעֵל), which often indicates a reflexive or reciprocal action. The root ש.מ.ש relates to using or serving. 'להשתמש' means 'to use' in the sense of making use of something for a purpose.

idioms.usage: הוא הִשְׁתַּמֵּשׁ בְּהִזְדַּמְּנוּת לְלַמֵּד אוֹתָם.
לֹא טוֹב לְהִשְׁתַּמֵּשׁ בְּשֵׁם ה' לַשָּׁוְא.

examples.translation: They entered the house to warm up.
Please do not enter this room.

niknas.notes: This verb is in binyan Nif'al (נִפְעַל), which often has a passive or reflexive meaning. The root כ.נ.ס relates to entering and gathering. 'להיכנס' means 'to enter' or 'to go in'.
related_words: הִכְנִיס (to insert, to bring in; Hif'il)

idioms.usage: הוא נִכְנַס לְתוֹךְ הָעִנְיָנִים וְהִבִּין אֶת הַמַּצָּב.
בוא נַחְלוֹק וְנִכָּנֵס לְחַדָּרִים.

examples.translation: He explained the law to the students.

examples.hebrew: אֵינִי מֵבִין, אַתְּ יְכוֹלָה לְהַסְבִּיר לִי?
examples.transliteration: Eini mevín, at yecholá lehasbír li?
examples.translation: I don't understand; can you explain to me?

hisbir.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often expresses causative actions. The root ס.ב.ר is associated with reasoning and explanation.

idioms.usage: הוא הִסְבִּיר פָּנִים לָאוֹרְחִים.
הַמּוֹרֶה הִסְבִּיר לָנוּ אֶת הַמְּצֻפֶּה מִמֶּנּוּ.

examples.translation: I feel that it's cold.
She felt tired after the run.

hirgish.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), indicating causative action. The root ר.ג.ש relates to feeling and emotion. 'להרגיש' means 'to feel' or 'to sense'.

idioms.usage: הוא הִרְגִּישׁ בְּבַיִת בַּמָּקוֹם הֶחָדָשׁ.
אֲנִי מַרְגִּישׁ טוֹב הַיּוֹם.

examples.translation: She expresses her opinion at the meeting.
The author expressed original ideas.

hivía.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root ב-י-ע is associated with expression and utterance. 'להביע' means 'to express' feelings, thoughts, or ideas.

idioms.usage: היא הִבִּיעָה תּוֹדָה לְכָל הַמְּשַׁתְּתְּפִים.
ההוֹרִים הִבִּיעוּ דְּאָגָה עַל הַמַּצָּב.

paal.note: Different meaning; relates to bursting or erupting

examples.translation: He stayed at the place for several days.
We are staying inside the room.

shaheh.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ש.ה.ה is associated with staying or remaining. It is typically used to indicate staying in a specific location or state.

idioms.usage: הוא שָׁהָה בְּדֶּרֶךְ אַרְכָּה וְהִגִּיעַ לִיְשִיבָת.
הם היוֹצְרִים שְׁהַיַּת חִירוּם בַּמָּקוֹם.

examples.translation: He locked the door at night.

examples.hebrew: אֲנַחנוּ נוֹעֲלִים אֶת הַחֲנוּת בְּשָׂעָה שֵׁשׁ.
examples.transliteration: Anachnú noalím et ha-chanút be-sa'á shésh.
examples.translation: We close the shop at six.

naal.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root נ-ע-ל is associated with closing or locking actions. It is often used for doors, gates, and shoes.

idioms.usage: הם נָעֲלוּ אַת הַשוריָר בְּלַיְלָה.
באמצךשעת שעה מִזְרָחית נעוֹל.

examples.hebrew: הסרט הזה הִשְׁפִּיעַ עלי בצורה עמוקה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-séret ha-ze hishpía alai be-tzurá amuká.
examples.translation: This movie influenced me deeply.

examples.hebrew: הם מַשְׁפִּיעִים רבות על דעת הקהל.
examples.transliteration: Hem mashpi'ím rabot al da'at ha-kahál.
examples.translation: They greatly influence public opinion.

hishpia.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root ש-פ-ע relates to influence and abundance.

idioms.usage: התזונה הבריאה מַשְׁפִּיעָה טוֹב על הבריאות.
העישון מַשְׁפִּיעַ רַע על הריאות.

hitnaheg.root_meaning: Related to driving, leading, or behaving

examples.translation: The child behaves excellently in kindergarten.

examples.hebrew: אֲנַחנוּ צְרִיכִים לְהִתְנַהֵג בְּכָבוֹד זֶה לַזֶה.
examples.transliteration: Anachnu tzrichím lehitnahég be-kavód ze la-ze.
examples.translation: We need to behave respectfully toward each other.

hitnaheg.notes: This verb is in binyan Hitpa'el (הִתְפַּעֵל), which often indicates reflexive or reciprocal actions. The root נ-ה-ג is associated with driving, leading, or behaving. 'להתנהג' means 'to behave' or 'to conduct oneself'.

idioms.usage: הוא תמיד מִתְנַהֵג בְּיִשְׁרוּת.
אנא, הִתְנַהֲגוּ כָּרָאוּי בַּמִּפְגָּשׁ.

lehaksiv.root_meaning: Related to listening or paying attention

examples.translation: Please listen to the instructions.
The students listen to the teacher in class.

lehaksiv.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root ק-ש-ב is associated with listening and paying attention. 'להקשיב' means 'to listen' attentively or to pay close attention.

idioms.usage: הוא הִקְשִׁיב בְּקֹּשִׁי לִפְנֵי הַבְּדִיקָה.
הם נוֹתְנִים הַקְשֵׁב רַב לַפְּרָטִים.

examples.translation: I believe in your talents.
They believed that everything would be alright.

leha'amin.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root א-מ-נ is associated with belief, faith, and trust. 'להאמין' means 'to believe' or 'to have faith'.

idioms.usage: הוא מַאֲמִין בְּעַצְמוֹ וּבְיְכוֹלוֹתָיו.
זֶה קָשֶׁה לְהַאֲמִין שֶׁהוּא עָשָׂה זֹאת.

nifal.note: Less common in modern usage

examples.translation: I decide to go to the university.
They decided to change the plan.

lehakhlit.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root ח-ל-ט is associated with deciding or making a decision. 'להחליט' means 'to decide' or 'to determine'.

idioms.translation: decided that the time has come
idioms.usage: הוא הִחְלִיט שֶׁהַגִּיעַ הַזְּמַן לְהַפְסִיק לְעוּשֶׂק.
הַשּׁוֹפֵט הִחְלִיט לְטוֹבַת הַצַּד הַשֵּׁנִי.

examples.translation: I know him from school.
She recognized the place.

lehakir.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root נ-כ-ר is associated with recognition, acquaintance, and being foreign. 'להכיר' means 'to recognize', 'to know someone', or 'to be acquainted with'.

idioms.usage: הוא הִכִּיר בְּטָעוּתוֹ וּבִקֵּשׁ סְלִיחָה.
אֲנִי מַכִּיר טוֹבָה לְךָ עַל עֶזְרָתְךָ.

examples.translation: We are starting the lesson now.
She started learning Hebrew.

lehatkhil.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root ת-ח-ל is associated with beginning or starting. 'להתחיל' means 'to start' or 'to begin' an action or process.

idioms.usage: הוא הִתְחִיל מֵהַתְּחִלָּה לִכְתֹּב אֶת הַסֵּפֶר.

idioms.translation: starting off on the right foot
idioms.usage: אֲנַחְנוּ מְקַוִּים לְהַתְחִיל בְּרֶגֶל יָמִין.

examples.translation: I manage well without help.
She managed in the new city.

lehistader.notes: This verb is in binyan Hitpa'el (הִתְפַּעֵל), which often indicates reflexive or reciprocal actions. The root ס-ד-ר is associated with order and organization. 'להסתדר' means 'to manage', 'to get along', or 'to arrange oneself'. It can refer to both practical and social situations.

idioms.usage: הוּא מִסְתַּדֵּר עִם כֻּלָּם.
הִיא הִסְתַּדְּרָה לְאַרְגֵּל אֶל הַמָּקוֹם הֶחָדָשׁ.

examples.translation: I want to advance at work.
The developer is progressing in developing the program.

lehitkadem.notes: This verb is in binyan Hitpa'el (הִתְפַּעֵל), which often indicates reflexive or reciprocal actions. The root ק-ד-ם is associated with advancing or moving forward. 'להתקדם' means 'to progress' or 'to advance' physically, professionally, or in other contexts.

idioms.usage: הַטֶּכְנוֹלוֹגְיָה הִתְקַדְּמָה בְּצַעֲדֵי עֲנָק.
לְאָן אֲנַחְנוּ מִתְקַדְּמִים בַּמִּשְׁתָּר?

examples.translation: He stopped talking during the lesson.
I stop working at six o'clock.

lehafsik.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root פ-ס-ק is associated with stopping or ceasing. 'להפסיק' means 'to stop' or 'to cease' an action. It can be used both transitively ('to stop something') and intransitively ('to stop').

idioms.usage: הַחוֹלֶה הִפְסִיק לְנְשׁוֹם וְהוּבַל לְבֵּית הַחוֹלִים.
הַקִּהִילָה הִפְסִיקָה אֶת הַמִּנְהָג הַיָּשָׁן.

paal.note: Common in legal or formal contexts

examples.translation: He invited me to a party.
I order food online.

lehazmin.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root ז-מ-נ is associated with invitation and ordering. 'להזמין' means 'to invite' someone or 'to order' something like food or products.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִזְמִין אֶת עַצְמוֹ לַמְּסִבָּה.
יֵשׁ לָכֶם הַזְמָנָה פְּתוּחָה לִבְקֹר בְּכָל זְמַן.

nifal.note: Used less commonly

examples.translation: I am leaving the keys on the table.
She left me a message.

lehash'ir.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל) and is used to express leaving something behind or retaining something. The root ש-א-ר is associated with remaining or leaving behind.
similar_verbs: לְהַנִּיחַ (lehaníach) - to put down, to leave

idioms.usage: הַמּוֹפָע הִשְׁאִיר רֹשֶׁם עָמוֹק.
הַסִּפְר הַזֶּה מַשְׁאִיר טַעַם שֶׁל עוֹד.

examples.translation: I suggest that you start walking.
He suggested a new idea to us.

lehatzia.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root י-צ-ע is associated with proposing or offering. 'להציע' means 'to suggest', 'to propose', or 'to offer' something to someone.
similar_verbs: לְהוֹצִיעַ (lehotzí'a) - to bring out, to publish

idioms.usage: הוּא הִצִּיעַ לָהּ נִשּּׂוּאִין בַּחוֹפֶשׁ.
הִיא הִצִּיעָה לִי עֶזְרָה בַּפְּרוֹיֶקְט.

nifal.note: Rarely used in modern Hebrew

examples.translation: I am looking for a new job.

examples.hebrew: הִיא חִפְּשָׂה אֶת הַמַּפְתֵּחוֹת בְּכָל הַבַּיִת.
examples.transliteration: Hi chipésah et ha-maftechót be-chol ha-báyit.
examples.translation: She searched for the keys all over the house.

lechapes.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or deliberate action. The root ח-פ-שׂ is associated with searching or seeking. 'לחפש' means 'to search' or 'to look for' something actively.

idioms.usage: הַבַּחוּר חִפֵּשׂ אֶת הַצָּמוּד בִּבְגָדִים.
אַל תִּהְיֶה מְחַפֵּשׂ אֶת הַצָּרָה.

pu'al.note: Less commonly used in modern Hebrew

examples.translation: I will contact you tomorrow.
She called me yesterday.

lehitkasher.notes: This verb is in binyan Hitpa'el (הִתְפַּעֵל), which often indicates reflexive or reciprocal actions. The root ק-ש-ר is associated with connecting, binding, or tying. 'להתקשר' means 'to contact' or 'to get in touch', typically by phone or other means of communication.

idioms.usage: הַמְּנַהֵל הִתְקַשֵּׁר בִּי לְדַבֵּר עַל הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט.
אֲנִי צָרִיךְ לְהִתְקַשֵּׁר בּוֹ בְּדָחִיפּוּת.

examples.translation: He completed the essay on time.
We need to complete the project.

lehashlim.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root שׁ-ל-מ is associated with wholeness and completion. 'להשלים' means 'to complete' or 'to finish' something.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִשְׁלִים עִם הַמַּצָּב וְהִמְשִׁיךְ לַעֲבוֹד.
הַפְּרָטִים הַחֲדָשִׁים הִשְׁלִימוּ אֶת הַתְּמוּנָה.

nifal.note: Used to indicate something is being completed

lehavtiach.root_meaning: Related to security, trust, or promising

examples.translation: He promised me to arrive on time.

examples.hebrew: אֲנַחְנוּ מַבְטִיחִים לַעֲשׂוֹת הַכֹּל בִּכְדֵי לַעֲזֹר.
examples.transliteration: Anachnu mavtichim la'asot hakol bikdei la'azor.
examples.translation: We promise to do everything in order to help.

lehavtiach.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root ב-ט-ח is associated with trust, security, and assurance. 'להבטיח' means 'to promise' or 'to guarantee' something to someone.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִבְטִיחַ וְלֹא קִיֵּם אֶת דְּבָרוֹ.
הַסֶּרֶט הַזֶּה מַבְטִיחַ הַרְבֵּה.

nifal.note: Rarely used in modern Hebrew

examples.translation: I am trying to learn Hebrew.
They tried to solve the problem.

lenasot.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or repetitive action. The root נ-ס-ה is associated with trying or testing. 'לנסות' means 'to try' or 'to attempt' to do something.

idioms.usage: הוּא נִסָּה אֶת הַמַּזָּל בְּהַגְרָלָה.
תַּמְשִׁיךְ לְנַסּוֹת, וּלְבַסּוֹף תַּצְלִיחַ.

examples.translation: He discovered a new invention.
I discover giants in my journey.

legalot.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or intentional action. The root ג-ל-ה is associated with revealing, uncovering, or discovering. 'לגלות' means 'to discover' or 'to reveal' something that was previously hidden.

idioms.usage: הוּא לֹא גִּילָּה אֶת הַגַּלְגַּל, אֲבָל זֶה רַעֲיוֹן טוֹב.
הַמַּדְרִיךְ אָמַר שֶׁאֲנִי גִּילִּיתִי אֶת הָאֵשׁ.

examples.translation: I receive a letter from a friend.
She received an award for her achievements.

lekabel.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often conveys intensive or repeated action. The root ק-ב-ל is associated with receiving, accepting, or welcoming. 'לקבל' means 'to receive' or 'to accept' something.

idioms.usage: הוּא קִיבֵּל אֶת הַהַחְלָטָה שֶׁל הַצֶּוֶת.
אֲנַחְנוּ מְקַבְּלִים אֶת פָּנֵי הָאוֹרְחִים.

examples.translation: I choose to study music.
They chose a new project.

livchor.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), which is the basic active form. The root ב-ח-ר relates to choosing or selecting. 'לבחור' means 'to choose' or 'to select' something from among options.

idioms.usage: הוּא בָּחַר לַעֲשׂוֹת אֶת הַדָּבָר הַנָּכוֹן.
הִיא הִיא בְּחִירַת לִבּוֹ.

examples.translation: I help my friends.
She helped us with the goal.

la'azor.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), which is the most common verb pattern in Hebrew. The root ע-ז-ר is associated with helping or assisting. 'לעזור' means 'to help' or 'to assist' someone in need.
related_words: עֶזוּר (ezúr) - region (note: different meaning but same root)

idioms.usage: הוּא עָזַר לְעַצְמוֹ לְהַשִּׂיג אֶת הַמַּטָּרָה.
לָמַדְתִּי קוּרְס בְּעֶזְרָה רִאשׁוֹנָה.

examples.translation: I want to ask a question.
The students ask questions during the lesson.

lish'ol.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), which is the simple active form. The root ש-א-ל is associated with asking or questioning. 'לשאול' means 'to ask' a question or to inquire about something.

idioms.usage: הוּא שָׁאַל בְּשָׁלוֹם חֲבֵרוֹ.
אֲנַחְנוּ צְרִיכִים לִשְׁאוֹל עַל הַדֶּרֶךְ.

nifal.note: Used less commonly in modern Hebrew

piel.note: In modern Hebrew, 'לשאול' in Pa'al can also mean 'to borrow,' though 'להשאיל' in Hif'il is more common for 'to lend.'

examples.translation: I remember this day.

examples.hebrew: הִיא לֹא זָכְרָה אֶת הַשֵּׁם שֶׁלּוֹ.
examples.transliteration: Hi lo zachrá et ha-shem shelo.
examples.translation: She did not remember his name.

lizkor.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), which is the basic active form. The root ז-כ-ר is associated with remembering and memory. 'לזכור' means 'to remember' or 'to recall' something.

idioms.usage: זְכֹר אֶת הַיּוֹם הַזֶּה לֵעָד.
הוּא זָכַר אוֹתָם לְטוֹב.

examples.translation: I want to buy a new book.
They bought a used car.

liknot.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the basic active verb pattern. The root ק-נ-ה is associated with buying or acquiring. 'לקנות' means 'to buy' or 'to purchase' goods or services.
related_words: קַנַּאי (kaná'i) - fanatical, zealot (different meaning but same root)

idioms.usage: הַמּוּסִיקָה קָנְתָה אֶת לִבָּהּ.
הַסּוֹפֵר קָנָה עוֹלָם בְּסִפְרוֹ הַמֻּפְלָא.

examples.translation: He opens the door.
Can you open the medicine?

liftoach.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), which is the basic active pattern in Hebrew. The root פ-ת-ח is associated with opening and beginning. 'לפתוח' means 'to open' physical objects like doors, books, or metaphorically, to start something new.

idioms.usage: הוּא פָּתַח דַּף חָדָשׁ בְּקָרֵיירָה שֶׁלּוֹ.
הַסִּפְר פָּתַח לִי אֶת הָעֵינַיִם.

letaken.root_meaning: Related to fixing, correcting, or improving

examples.translation: He is fixing his car.

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי צָרִיךְ לְתַקֵּן אֶת הַטָּעוּיוֹת בַּסִּפְרָה.
examples.transliteration: Ani tzairích letakén et ha-taúyot bas-sifrát.
examples.translation: I need to fix the mistakes in the book.

letaken.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or repetitive action. The root ת-ק-ן is associated with correction and improvement. 'לתקן' means 'to fix', 'to repair', or 'to correct' something that is broken or incorrect.

idioms.usage: הַמוּרֶה תִּקֵּן גָּדוֹל לַתַּלְמִיד.
הוּא לָקַח אֶת הַמַּכְשִׁיר לָמִרָק לְתַקֵּן.

examples.translation: He told me a funny story.

examples.hebrew: אני רוצה לספר לך את האמת.
examples.transliteration: Ani rotze lesapér lecha et ha'emet.
examples.translation: I want to tell you the truth.

lesaper.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or iterative action. The root ס-פ-ר is associated with recounting, telling, or counting. 'לספר' means 'to tell' a story or an account of something.

idioms.usage: הוּא סִיפֵּר לֹא חָדֶג לַאֲבוֹת.
בְּכיתה, הוּא סִיפֵּר מַעֲשָׂה עַל הָעִיר.

examples.translation: I want to succeed in my studies.
They succeeded in their task.

lehatsliach.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root צ-ל-ח is associated with success and prosperity. 'להצליח' means 'to succeed', typically in a task, endeavor, or challenge.

idioms.usage: המפעל הזה נחשב להצלחה על נריקית.
הִצְלִיחַ בְּכָל תָּכוֹן לְהַגִּיעַ לַמִּשְׁתַּנּוֹת.

examples.translation: They destroyed the important document.
They must stop destroying the environment.

lehashmid.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root ש-מ-ד is associated with destruction or obliteration. 'להשמיד' means 'to destroy' or 'to annihilate' something completely.

idioms.usage: הם השמידו עשרה מתוך מאה.
הַמִּתְנַגֵּד שָׁמַד בָּרִיבּוּעַ הָרִאשׁוֹן.

examples.translation: I forgot the book at home.
She is forgetting to buy bread.

lishkoach.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern in Hebrew. The root ש-כ-ח relates to forgetting or neglecting, and 'לִשְׁכּוֹחַ' is typically transitive, often followed by a direct object (e.g., forgetting something) or an infinitive (e.g., forgetting to do something).

idioms.usage: אַחֲרֵי הַוִּכּוּחַ הוּא שָׁכַח מֵהַלֵּב.

examples.translation: I am waiting for the bus at the station.
They waited for the teacher in the classroom.

lechakot.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or deliberate actions. The root ח-כ-ה relates to waiting or expecting, and 'לְחַכּוֹת' typically implies waiting for something or someone specific, often followed by the preposition לְ (le-).

idioms.translation: waited for the moon (waited a long time)
idioms.usage: הוּא חִכָּה לַיָּרֵחַ עַד שֶׁהִגִּיעָה הָעֶזְרָה.

lashevet.root_meaning: Related to sitting, dwelling, or residing

examples.translation: I am sitting on the chair.
They sat in the garden all day.

lashevet.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern in Hebrew. The root י-ש-ב relates to sitting, dwelling, or residing, and 'לָשֶׁבֶת' is intransitive, often used with prepositions like עַל (al, 'on') or בְּ (be, 'in') to indicate location.
related_words: יְשִׁיבָה (yeshiva) - sitting, session; also a religious school

idioms.usage: בַּדִּיון הוּא יָשַׁב עַל הַגָּדֵר וְלֹא בָּחַר.

meaning: to seat, to cause to sit

laamod.root_meaning: Related to standing, enduring, or resisting

examples.translation: I am standing next to the window.
They stood in line for thirty minutes.

laamod.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern in Hebrew. The root ע-מ-ד relates to standing, enduring, or resisting, and 'לַעֲמוֹד' is intransitive, often used with prepositions like לְיַד (leyad, 'next to') or בְּ (be, 'in') to indicate position or context.
similar_verbs: לָקוּם (lakum) - to stand up, to rise

idioms.translation: stood by his word (kept a promise)
idioms.usage: הוּא עָמַד בַּמִּלָּה שֶׁנָּתַן לָנוּ.

meaning: to set up, to cause to stand

levashel.root_meaning: Related to cooking or preparing food

examples.translation: I am cooking rice in the kitchen.
She cooked a cake for the birthday.

levashel.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or deliberate actions like cooking. The root ב-ש-ל relates to cooking or preparing food, and 'לְבַשֵּׁל' is typically transitive, taking a direct object (e.g., food being cooked).

idioms.usage: הוּא בִּשֵּׁל בְּדָמוֹ כְּשֶׁשָּׁמַע אֶת הַחֲדָשׁוֹת.

examples.translation: I am dancing at the party.
They danced at the wedding until morning.

lirkod.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern in Hebrew. The root ר-ק-ד relates to dancing or leaping, and 'לִרְקוֹד' is intransitive, often used with prepositions like בְּ (be-, 'at') or עַל (al, 'on') to indicate location or context.

idioms.translation: danced to his flute (followed his lead)
idioms.usage: הִיא רָקְדָה לְפִי הַחָלִיל שֶׁלּוֹ בְּכָל הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט.

meaning: to choreograph, to cause to dance (less common)

examples.translation: I am jumping on the bed.
They jumped into the water in the pool.

likpotz.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern in Hebrew. The root ק-פ-ץ relates to jumping or leaping, and 'לִקְפּוֹץ' is intransitive, often used with prepositions like עַל (al, 'on') or לְ (le-, 'to') to indicate direction or surface.

idioms.translation: jumped out of skin and flesh (was extremely excited)
idioms.usage: הוּא קָפַץ מֵעוֹר וּבָשָׂר כְּשֶׁשָּׁמַע עַל הַזְּכִיָּה.

meaning: to cause to jump, to bounce

examples.translation: I am swimming in the pool every day.
They swam in the sea in the summer.

lisachot.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern in Hebrew. The root ש-ח-ה relates to swimming or flowing, and 'לִשְׂחוֹת' is intransitive, often used with prepositions like בְּ (be-, 'in') to indicate location.

idioms.usage: הוּא שָׂחָה בֵּין הַטִּפּוֹת וְלֹא נִרְטַב בַּמְּרִיבָה.

examples.translation: The bird is flying in the sky.
We flew to Europe in the summer.

lauf.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern in Hebrew. The root ע-ו-ף relates to flying or soaring, and 'לָעוּף' is intransitive, often used with prepositions like בְּ (be-, 'in') or לְ (le-, 'to') to indicate location or destination.

idioms.translation: flew to a world all good (died)
idioms.usage: אַחֲרֵי מַחֲלָה קָשָׁה, הוּא עָף לְעוֹלָם שֶׁכֻּלּוֹ טוֹב.

laalot.root_meaning: Related to ascending, rising, or going up

examples.translation: I am climbing the mountain in the morning.
They climbed to the apartment via the stairs.

laalot.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern in Hebrew. The root ע-ל-ה relates to ascending or rising, and 'לַעֲלוֹת' is intransitive, often used with prepositions like עַל (al, 'on') or לְ (le-, 'to') to indicate destination or surface. It can also mean 'to go up' in various contexts (e.g., stairs, prices, immigration to Israel).

idioms.translation: climbed to the head (went to his head, became arrogant)
idioms.usage: אַחֲרֵי הַנִּצָּחוֹן, הַהַצְלָחָה עָלְתָה לוֹ לָרֹאשׁ.

meaning: to raise, to cause to go up

examples.translation: I am falling off the ladder every day.
They fell into bed from exhaustion.

lipol.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern in Hebrew. The root נ-פ-ל relates to falling or dropping, and 'לִפּוֹל' is intransitive, often used with prepositions like מִ (mi-, 'from') or לְ (le-, 'to') to indicate source or destination. It can also mean 'to fall asleep' or 'to fail' in certain contexts.

idioms.usage: הוּא נָפַל לְרַגְלֵי הַמּוֹרֶה לְהַאֲרִיךְ אֶת הַמּוֹעֵד.

meaning: to cause to fall, to drop

lehitcharet.root_meaning: Related to regret, repentance, or retraction

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מִתְחַרֵט עַל הַהַחְלָטָה לִקְנוֹת אֶת הָאוֹטוֹ.
examples.transliteration: Ani mitcharet al hahachlata liknot et ha’oto.
examples.translation: I am regretting the decision to buy the car.

examples.hebrew: הִיא הִתְחַרְטָה אַחֲרֵי שֶׁדִּבְּרָה אֶת הַמּוֹרָה.
examples.transliteration: Hi hitcharta acharei shedibra et hamora.
examples.translation: She regretted after speaking to the teacher.

lehitcharet.notes: This verb is in the Hitpa'el binyan (הִתְפַּעֵל), often used for reflexive or reciprocal actions. The root ח-ר-ט relates to regret or retraction, and 'לְהִתְחַרֵט' is reflexive, expressing personal remorse, typically used with עַל (al, 'about') to specify the cause of regret. Its emotional nuance and Hitpa'el structure make it intermediate.
similar_verbs: לְשַׁנּוֹת דַּעַת (leshanot da’at) - to change one’s mind

idioms.translation: regretted at this price (regretted too late or at great cost)
idioms.usage: הוּא הִתְחַרֵט בִּמְחִיר הַזֹּאת אַחֲרֵי שֶׁאִבֵּד אֶת הַכֹּל.

lachkor.root_meaning: Related to investigating, researching, or exploring

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי חוֹקֵר אֶת הַתְּאוּנָה שֶׁקָּרְתָה אֶתְמוֹל.
examples.transliteration: Ani choker et hat’una shekarta etmol.
examples.translation: I am investigating the accident that happened yesterday.
They investigated the case with dedication.

lachkor.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern in Hebrew, but its transitive nature and use in formal or intellectual contexts (e.g., research, police work) make it intermediate. The root ח-ק-ר relates to investigating or researching, and 'לַחְקוֹר' requires a direct object (what is investigated), often with אֶת (et).

idioms.usage: הַשּׁוֹטֵר חָקַר עַד הַסּוֹף כְּדֵי לִמְצוֹא אֶת הָאֱמֶת.

leitrakez.root_meaning: Related to concentrating, focusing, or gathering

examples.translation: I am concentrating on my exam now.
They concentrated on the plan before the meeting.

leitrakez.notes: This verb is in the Hitpa'el binyan (הִתְפַּעֵל), often used for reflexive or intensive actions. The root ר-כ-ז relates to concentrating or focusing, and 'לְהִתְרַכֵּז' is reflexive, implying self-directed focus, typically used with בְּ (be-, 'on') to specify the object of concentration. Its mental focus and Hitpa'el structure make it intermediate.

idioms.translation: concentrated on the garnish (focused on the minor instead of the main)
idioms.usage: הוּא הִתְרַכֵּז בַּטַּפֵּל וְשָׁכַח אֶת הָעִקָּר.

lehitnatzel.root_meaning: Related to apologizing, rescuing, or delivering

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מִתְנַצֵּל עַל הָאִחוּר שֶׁלִּי לַפְּגִישָׁה.
examples.transliteration: Ani mitnatzel al ha’ichur sheli lapgisha.
examples.translation: I am apologizing for my delay to the meeting.

examples.hebrew: הִיא הִתְנַצְּלָה לִפְנֵי הַמּוֹרָה עַל הַטָּעוּת.
examples.transliteration: Hi hitnatzla lifnei hamora al hata’ut.
examples.translation: She apologized to the teacher for the mistake.

lehitnatzel.notes: This verb is in the Hitpa'el binyan (הִתְפַּעֵל), often used for reflexive or reciprocal actions. The root נ-צ-ל relates to rescuing or delivering, but in Hitpa'el, 'לְהִתְנַצֵּל' means to apologize, a reflexive act of self-expression. It’s typically used with עַל (al, 'for') to specify the reason or לִפְנֵי (lifnei, 'to') for the recipient. Its Hitpa'el form and social nuance make it intermediate.
similar_verbs: לְבַקֵּשׁ סְלִיחָה (levakesh slicha) - to ask for forgiveness

idioms.translation: apologized with a heavy heart (apologized reluctantly)
idioms.usage: הוּא הִתְנַצֵּל בְּלֵב כָּבֵד כִּי לֹא רָצָה לְהוֹדוֹת בַּטָּעוּת.

ledamot.root_meaning: Related to imagining, resembling, or likening

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְדַמֶּה אֶת הַחֲלוֹם שֶׁלִּי כָּל יוֹם.
examples.transliteration: Ani medamme et hachalom sheli kol yom.
examples.translation: I am imagining my dream every day.

examples.hebrew: הֵם דִּמּוּ אֶת הָעֹלָם בְּלִי מִלְחָמוֹת.
examples.transliteration: Hem dimmu et ha’olam bli milchamot.
examples.translation: They imagined a world without wars.

ledamot.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or causative actions. The root ד-מ-ה relates to imagining or resembling, and 'לְדַמּוֹת' is transitive in Piel, requiring a direct object (what is imagined), often marked with אֶת (et). Its cognitive nature and Piel structure make it intermediate, distinct from simpler Qal verbs.

idioms.translation: imagined a figure in his heart (envisioned deeply)
idioms.usage: הוּא דִּמָּה דְּמוּת בְּלִבּוֹ שֶׁל עֹלָם מֻשְׁלָם.

lehit’akesh.root_meaning: Related to insisting, persisting, or being stubborn

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מִתְעַקֵּשׁ עַל הַתּוֹכְנִית הַזּוֹ לַפְּגִישָׁה.
examples.transliteration: Ani mit’akesh al hatokhnit hazo lapgisha.
examples.translation: I am insisting on this plan for the meeting.

examples.hebrew: הֵם הִתְעַקְּשׁוּ לָלֶכֶת לַמְּסִיבָּה לַמְרוֹת הַגֶּשֶׁם.
examples.transliteration: Hem hit’akshu lalekhet lamesiba lamrot hageshem.
examples.translation: They insisted on going to the party despite the rain.

lehit’akesh.notes: This verb is in the Hitpa'el binyan (הִתְפַּעֵל), often used for reflexive or intensive actions. The root ע-ק-ש relates to persistence or stubbornness, and 'לְהַתְּעַקֵּשׁ' is reflexive, implying self-directed determination. It’s typically used with עַל (al, 'on') for the issue or לְ (le-, 'to') with an infinitive for the action insisted upon. Its Hitpa'el form and nuanced persistence make it intermediate.

idioms.usage: הִיא הִתְעַקְּשָׁה עַד הַסּוֹף לְקַבֵּל אֶת הַתְּשׁוּבָה שֶׁרָצְתָה.

latarom.root_meaning: Related to contributing, donating, or uplifting

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי תּוֹרֵם כֶּסֶף לָאֲגֻדָּה כָּל חֹדֶשׁ.
examples.transliteration: Ani torem kesef la’aguda kol chodesh.
examples.translation: I am contributing money to the organization every month.
They contributed new ideas to the project.

latarom.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern in Hebrew, but its transitive nature and varied applications (e.g., donating money, offering ideas) make it intermediate. The root ת-ר-ם relates to contributing or uplifting, and 'לְתַרֹם' typically takes a direct object (what is contributed), often with לְ (le-, 'to') indicating the recipient or purpose.

idioms.usage: הוּא תָּרַם אֶת חֶלְקוֹ לְהַצְלָחַת הַצּוֹמֵת.

levalbel.root_meaning: Related to confusing, mixing, or disrupting

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְבַלבֵּל אֶת הַתַּלְמִידִים עִם הַשְּׁאֵלוֹת שֶׁלִּי.
examples.transliteration: Ani mevalbel et hatalmidim im hashe’elot sheli.
examples.translation: I am confusing the students with my questions.
They confused the plan by mistake.

levalbel.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or causative actions. The root ב-ל-ב-ל (a four-letter root) relates to mixing or disrupting, and 'לְבַלבֵּל' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what or whom is confused), typically marked with אֶת (et). Its Piel form and causative effect make it intermediate, distinct from simpler Qal verbs.

idioms.usage: הוּא בִּלבֵּל אֶת הַקֵּן כְּשֶׁדִּבֵּר עַל הַנּוֹשֵׂא הָרָגִישׁ.

livroach.root_meaning: Related to escaping, fleeing, or running away

examples.translation: I am escaping from the house every morning.
They escaped from the prison at night.

livroach.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern in Hebrew, but its intransitive nature, irregular conjugation due to the guttural ח, and contextual use make it intermediate. The root ב-ר-ח relates to fleeing, and 'לִבְרֹחַ' is typically used with מִן (min, 'from') or מֵ (me-, 'from') to indicate what is escaped. Its irregularity and narrative nuance distinguish it from simpler Qal verbs.

idioms.usage: הוּא בָּרַח מֵהָאֱמֶת כְּשֶׁסִּפֵּר שְׁקָרִים.

meaning: to be smuggled, to be made to escape (rare)

lehamlitz.root_meaning: Related to recommending, advising, or filling

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מַמְלִיץ עַל הַסֵּפֶר הַזֶּה לְכָל הַחֲבֵרִים.
examples.transliteration: Ani mamlitz al hasefer haze lechol hachaverim.
examples.translation: I am recommending this book to all the friends.

examples.hebrew: הִיא הִמְלִיצָה לִי לִקְנוֹת אֶת הַמִּשְׁקָפַיִם הָאֵלֶּה.
examples.transliteration: Hi himlitza li liknot et hamishkafayim ha’ele.
examples.translation: She recommended to me to buy these glasses.

lehamlitz.notes: This verb is in the Hif'il binyan (הִפְעִיל), typically used for causative actions. The root מ-ל-ץ relates to advising or recommending, and 'לְהַמְלִיץ' is transitive, often taking a direct object (what is recommended) with עַל (al, 'on') or an indirect object with לְ (le-, 'to') followed by an infinitive or recipient. Its Hif'il form and advisory nuance make it intermediate.

idioms.translation: recommended with a warm heart (recommended enthusiastically)
idioms.usage: הוּא הִמְלִיץ בְּחֹם לֵב עַל הַמּוֹפֵע הַזֶּה.

lilchosh.root_meaning: Related to whispering or speaking softly

examples.translation: I am whispering to the friends in the library.
They whispered secrets in the dark.

lilchosh.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern in Hebrew, but its intransitive nature, irregular conjugation due to the guttural ח (affecting vowel patterns), and specific quiet-speech context make it intermediate. The root ל-ח-ש relates to whispering, and 'לִלְחוֹשׁ' can be used alone or with לְ (le-, 'to') for the recipient, or with a direct object (what is whispered). Its irregularity and nuance distinguish it from basic Qal verbs.

idioms.translation: whispered in the ear (shared a secret)
idioms.usage: הִיא לָחֲשָׁה בְּאֹזֶן שֶׁהַמִּבְחָן בּוּטַּל.

lesator.root_meaning: Related to contradicting, opposing, or demolishing

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי סוֹתֵר אֶת הַדְּבָרִים שֶׁאָמַר הַמּוֹרֶה.
examples.transliteration: Ani soter et had’varim she’amar hamore.
examples.translation: I am contradicting the things the teacher said.
They contradicted the claims in the discussion.

lesator.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), but its transitive nature, irregular conjugation due to the guttural ת (affecting vowel patterns, e.g., סָתַרְתִּי), and abstract intellectual sense make it advanced. The root ס-ת-ר relates to opposing or demolishing, and 'לְסָתוֹר' requires a direct object (what is contradicted), often with אֶת (et). Its rarity and conceptual depth distinguish it from simpler verbs.

idioms.usage: בַּנְּאוּם הוּא סָתַר אֶת עַצְמוֹ וְאִבֵּד אֶת הַקָּהָל.

lehachin.root_meaning: Related to preparing, establishing, or making ready

examples.translation: I am preparing the food for the evening.
They prepared a plan for the birthday.

lehachin.notes: This verb is in the Hif'il binyan (הִפְעִיל), typically used for causative actions. The root כ-ו-ן relates to establishing or preparing, and 'לְהָכִין' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is prepared), often with אֶת (et). It can also take לְ (le-, 'for') to indicate purpose or recipient. Its Hif'il form, causative sense, and everyday utility make it intermediate.

idioms.usage: הוּא הֵכִין אֶת הַשְּׁטָח לַשִּׂיחָה הַקָּשָׁה.

lehavtiach.root_meaning: Related to promising, assuring, or making secure

examples.translation: I am promising to come early tomorrow.
She promised me help with the exam.

lehavtiach.notes: This verb is in the Hif'il binyan (הִפְעִיל), typically used for causative actions. The root ב-ט-ח relates to security or assurance, and 'לְהַבְטִיחַ' is transitive, often taking a direct object (what is promised) or לְ (le-, 'to') with an infinitive or recipient. Its Hif'il form and interpersonal commitment make it intermediate, distinct from simpler verbs like 'to say' (לְהַגִּיד).

idioms.translation: promised mountains of gold (made extravagant promises)
idioms.usage: הוּא הִבְטִיחַ הֲרֵי זָהָב אֲבָל לֹא קִיֵּם.

letaken.root_meaning: Related to repairing, fixing, or correcting

examples.translation: I am repairing the car in the garage.
They repaired the mistake in the document.

letaken.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root ת-ק-ן relates to fixing or correcting, and 'לְתַקֵּן' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is repaired), typically marked with אֶת (et). It can apply to physical repairs (e.g., objects) or abstract corrections (e.g., mistakes). Its Piel form and versatility make it intermediate.
similar_verbs: לְבַשֵּׁל (levashel) - to cook (in a preparatory sense)

idioms.translation: repaired the world (made a significant positive change)
idioms.usage: הִיא תִּיקְּנָה אֶת הָעוֹלָם בְּמַעֲשֶׂיהָ הַטּוֹבִים.

lehakhriz.root_meaning: Related to announcing, proclaiming, or declaring

examples.translation: I am announcing the results of the competition.

examples.hebrew: הֵם הִכְרִיזוּ עַל תָּכְנִית חֲדָשָׁה לַשָּׁנָה.
examples.transliteration: Hem hikhrizu al tokhnit chadasha lashana.
examples.translation: They announced a new plan for the year.

lehakhriz.notes: This verb is in the Hif'il binyan (הִפְעִיל), typically used for causative actions. The root כ-ר-ז relates to proclaiming or making known, and 'לְהַכְרִיז' is transitive, often taking a direct object (what is announced) with עַל (al, 'on') to specify the subject matter. Its Hif'il form and declarative context make it intermediate, distinct from simpler verbs like 'to say' (לְהַגִּיד).

idioms.usage: הוּא הִכְרִיז מִלְחָמָה עַל הַתּוֹכְנִית הַחֲדָשָׁה.

lehazhir.root_meaning: Related to warning, cautioning, or making aware

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מַזְהִיר אֶת הַיְּלָדִים מִפְּנֵי הַסַּכָּנָה.
examples.transliteration: Ani mazhir et hayeladim mipnei hasakana.
examples.translation: I am warning the children about the danger.

examples.hebrew: הִיא הִזְהִירָה אוֹתִי לֹא לָלֶכֶת לְשָׁם.
examples.transliteration: Hi hizhira oti lo lalekhet l’sham.
examples.translation: She warned me not to go there.

lehazhir.notes: This verb is in the Hif'il binyan (הִפְעִיל), typically used for causative actions. The root ז-ה-ר relates to caution or awareness, and 'לְהַזְהִיר' is transitive, often taking a direct object (whom is warned) with אֶת (et), and optionally מִפְּנֵי (mipnei, 'about') or לֹא (lo, 'not') with an infinitive to specify the warning. Its Hif'il form and cautionary nuance make it intermediate.

idioms.translation: warned about this (gave a specific caution)
idioms.usage: הַמּוֹרֶה הִזְהִיר מִפְּנֵי הַזֹּאת לִפְנֵי הַמִּבְחָן.

lehamtsia.root_meaning: Related to inventing, finding, or creating

examples.translation: I am inventing a new story for the children.
They invented a device to save time.

lehamtsia.notes: This verb is in the Hif'il binyan (הִפְעִיל), typically used for causative actions. The root מ-צ-א relates to finding or creating, and 'לְהַמְצִיא' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is invented), often with אֶת (et), though it can omit it in informal use. It can also mean 'to make up' (e.g., a story). Its Hif'il form and creative nuance make it intermediate.
similar_verbs: לְתַקֵּן (letaken) - to repair (in a constructive sense)

idioms.translation: invented the wheel (did something obvious or redundant)
idioms.usage: הוּא הִמְצִיא אֶת הַגַּלְגַּל כְּשֶׁהִצִּיעַ פִּתְרוֹן יָדוּעַ.

lehitcharot.root_meaning: Related to competing, contending, or striving

examples.translation: I am competing with the friends in the game.
They competed for the prize in the competition.

lehitcharot.notes: This verb is in the Hitpa'el binyan (הִתְפַּעֵל), often used for reflexive or reciprocal actions. The root ח-ר-ה relates to striving or contending, and 'לְהִתְחָרוֹת' implies reciprocal competition, typically used with עִם (im, 'with') for opponents or עַל (al, 'for') for the prize or goal. Its Hitpa'el form and reciprocal nuance make it intermediate.
similar_verbs: לְהַתְמַקֵּד (lehitmaked) - to focus (in a striving sense)

idioms.usage: הֵם הִתְחָרוּ עַל כָּל צַעַד בַּמֵּרוֹץ הַזֶּה.

lefa’aneach.root_meaning: Related to deciphering, decoding, or interpreting

examples.translation: I am deciphering the secret code.

examples.hebrew: הֵם פִּעֲנְחוּ אֶת הַמִּסְתּוֹרִין שֶׁל הַסֵּפֶר.
examples.transliteration: Hem pi’anchu et hamistorin shel hasefer.
examples.translation: They deciphered the mysteries of the book.

lefa’aneach.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root פ-ע-נ-ח (a four-letter root) relates to decoding or interpreting, and 'לְפַעֲנֵחַ' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is deciphered), typically marked with אֶת (et). Its specialized intellectual context, four-letter root, and rarity make it advanced, beyond simpler Piel verbs like 'to repair' (לְתַקֵּן).
similar_verbs: לְהַמְצִיא (lehamtsia) - to invent (in a creative sense)

idioms.usage: הִיא פִּעֲנְחָה אֶת הַלֵּב שֶׁלּוֹ בְּדִיּוּק רַב.

le’ar’er.root_meaning: Related to undermining, shaking, or destabilizing

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְעַרְעֵר אֶת הַסֵּדֶר בַּצּוֹמֵת הַזֹּו.
examples.transliteration: Ani me’ar’er et haseder batzomet hazo.
examples.translation: I am undermining the order in this team.

examples.hebrew: הֵם עֵרְעֲרוּ אֶת הַיְּצִיבוּת שֶׁל הַמֶּמְשָׁלָה.
examples.translation: They undermined the stability of the government.

le’ar’er.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root ע-ר-ע-ר (a four-letter root) relates to shaking or destabilizing, and 'לְעַרְעֵר' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is undermined), typically marked with אֶת (et). Its four-letter root, abstract meaning, and infrequent use in formal or political contexts make it advanced, beyond simpler Piel verbs like 'to repair' (לְתַקֵּן).

idioms.translation: undermined the foundations (shook the core principles)
idioms.usage: הַמְּחָאָה עֵרְעֲרָה אֶת הַיְּסוֹדוֹת שֶׁל הַמִּשְׁטָר.

leratzot.root_meaning: Related to reconciling, appeasing, or satisfying

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְרַצֶּה אֶת הַיְּחָסִים בֵּין הַחֲבֵרִים.
examples.transliteration: Ani meratze et hayachasim beyn hachaverim.
examples.translation: I am reconciling the relationships between the friends.

examples.hebrew: הֵם רִיצּוּ אֶת הַסְּתִירוֹת בֵּין הַצְּדָדִים.
examples.transliteration: Hem ritzo et hastirot beyn hatzdadim.
examples.translation: They reconciled the contradictions between the parties.

leratzot.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root ר-צ-ה relates to appeasing or satisfying, and 'לְרַצּוֹת' in Piel can mean 'to reconcile' (e.g., relationships, contradictions), 'to appease,' or 'to satisfy,' with context determining the sense. It’s transitive, typically taking a direct object with אֶת (et), and occasionally בֵּין (beyn, 'between') for parties involved. Its semantic flexibility, rarity, and formal tone make it advanced, beyond simpler Piel verbs like 'to repair' (לְתַקֵּן).
similar_verbs: לְתַקֵּן (letaken) - to repair (in a corrective sense)

idioms.translation: reconciled the heart (won over or appeased emotionally)
idioms.usage: הוּא רִיצָּה אֶת הַלֵּב שֶׁלָּהּ בְּמִלִּים רַכּוֹת.

lehachlit.root_meaning: Related to deciding, determining, or resolving

examples.translation: I am determining the plan for the evening.
They determined to come to the party.

lehachlit.notes: This verb is in the Hif'il binyan (הִפְעִיל), typically used for causative actions. The root ח-ל-ט relates to deciding or resolving, and 'לְהַחְלִיט' is transitive, often taking a direct object with עַל (al, 'on') for what is decided, or לְ (le-, 'to') with an infinitive for the action determined. Its frequent use in both casual and formal decision-making, combined with Hif'il complexity, makes it advanced yet moderately common, unlike rarer verbs like 'to reconcile' (לְרַצּוֹת).
similar_verbs: לְהַחְלִישׁ (lehachalish) - to weaken (unrelated but phonetically similar)

idioms.translation: determined with a cool head (decided calmly)
idioms.usage: הוּא הֶחְלִיט בְּרֹאשׁ קָר לֹא לְהִגָּרֵר לְוִכּוּחַ.

lachakor.root_meaning: Related to investigating, researching, or exploring

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי חוֹקֵר אֶת הַתְּאוּנָה שֶׁקָּרְתָה אֶתְמוֹל.
examples.transliteration: Ani choker et hat’una shekarta etmol.
examples.translation: I am investigating the accident that happened yesterday.
They investigated the case with dedication.

lachakor.notes: This verb is in the Pa'al binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern, but its transitive nature, intellectual depth, and use in formal or technical contexts elevate it to advanced. The root ח-ק-ר relates to exploring or researching, and 'לַחֲקוֹר' requires a direct object (what is investigated), often with אֶת (et). Its moderate frequency in investigative or research settings, combined with its nuanced application, distinguishes it from basic Pa'al verbs like 'to write' (לִכְתּוֹב).

idioms.usage: הַשּׁוֹטֵר חָקַר עַד הַסּוֹף לְגַלּוֹת אֶת הָאֱמֶת.

leshaknea.root_meaning: Related to persuading, convincing, or influencing

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְשַׁכְנֵעַ אֶת הַחֲבֵרִים לָבוֹא אִיתִּי.
examples.transliteration: Ani meshaknea et hachaverim lavo iti.
examples.translation: I am persuading the friends to come with me.

examples.hebrew: הֵם שִׁיכְנְעוּ אֶת הַקָּהָל בְּטִעוּנִים חֲזָקִים.
examples.transliteration: Hem shikhn’u et hakahal beti’unim chazakim.
examples.translation: They persuaded the audience with strong arguments.

leshaknea.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root ש-כ-נ-ע relates to convincing or influencing, and 'לְשַׁכְנֵעַ' is transitive, typically requiring a direct object (whom is persuaded) with אֶת (et), and often followed by לְ (le-, 'to') with an infinitive for the action persuaded. Its four-letter root, interpersonal nuance, and moderate frequency in persuasive contexts make it advanced yet practical, distinct from simpler Piel verbs like 'to repair' (לְתַקֵּן).
similar_verbs: לְהַחְלִיט (lehachlit) - to determine (in a decisive sense)
לְשַׁנוֹת דַּעַת (leshanot da’at) - to change (someone’s) mind

idioms.translation: persuaded with charming words (won over with eloquence)
idioms.usage: הִיא שִׁיכְנְעָה אֶת הַקָּהָל בְּדִבְרֵי חֵן וּבְחִיּוּךְ.

levarer.root_meaning: Related to clarifying, sorting out, or verifying

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְבָרֵר אֶת הַפְּרָטִים שֶׁל הַתָּאוּנָה.
examples.transliteration: Ani mevarer et hapratim shel hat’una.
examples.translation: I am clarifying the details of the accident.

examples.hebrew: הֵם בֵּירְרוּ אֶת הַמָּקוֹר שֶׁל הַשְּׁמוּעָה.
examples.transliteration: Hem bereru et hamakor shel hashmu’a.
examples.translation: They clarified the source of the rumor.

levarer.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root ב-ר-ר relates to sorting or making clear, and 'לְבָרֵר' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is clarified) with אֶת (et). It can also imply verifying or investigating to resolve uncertainty, adding depth to its use. Its moderate frequency in both casual and formal clarification contexts, combined with Piel complexity, makes it advanced yet practical, distinct from simpler Piel verbs like 'to repair' (לְתַקֵּן).

idioms.usage: הוּא בֵּירֵר עַד תּוֹם אֶת הַסִּבּוֹת לָאִחוּר.

leshaper.root_meaning: Related to improving, enhancing, or refining

examples.translation: I am improving my skills.

examples.hebrew: הֵם שִׁיפְּרוּ אֶת הַתּוֹכְנָה בְּגִירְסָה חֲדָשָׁה.
examples.transliteration: Hem shipru et hatokhna begirsa chadasha.
examples.translation: They improved the software with a new version.

leshaper.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root ש-פ-ר relates to enhancing or making better, and 'לְשַׁפֵּר' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is improved) with אֶת (et). It applies to tangible improvements (e.g., objects) or abstract enhancements (e.g., skills). Its moderate frequency in development or refinement contexts, combined with Piel complexity, makes it advanced yet practical, distinct from simpler Piel verbs like 'to repair' (לְתַקֵּן).

idioms.usage: הוּא שִׁיפֵּר אֶת הַבַּיִת עַד לֹא יִכּוֹל בְּחָדָשׁוֹת.

le’argen.root_meaning: Related to organizing, arranging, or structuring

examples.translation: I am organizing the party for the friends.

examples.hebrew: הֵם אֵירְגְּנוּ אֶת הַמִּשְׂרָד בְּסֵדֶר מֻפְלָא.
examples.translation: They organized the office in a wonderful order.

le’argen.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root א-ר-ג-ן relates to arranging or structuring, and 'לְאַרְגֵּן' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is organized) with אֶת (et), often followed by לְ (le-, 'for') to indicate purpose or recipients. Its four-letter root, moderate frequency in planning or structuring contexts, and Piel complexity make it advanced yet practical, distinct from simpler Piel verbs like 'to repair' (לְתַקֵּן).
similar_verbs: לְשַׁפֵּר (leshaper) - to improve (in a refining sense)

idioms.translation: organized the thoughts (put thoughts in order)
idioms.usage: הִיא אֵירְגְּנָה אֶת הַמַּחֲשָׁבוֹת לִפְנֵי הַפְּגִישָׁה.

lesayem.root_meaning: Related to concluding, finishing, or completing

examples.translation: I am concluding the game now.

examples.hebrew: הֵם סִייְּמוּ אֶת הַמוּזִיקָה בְּצוּרָה מֻשְׁלֶמֶת.
examples.transliteration: Hem siymu et hamuzika betzura mushlemet.
examples.translation: They concluded the music perfectly.

lesayem.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root ס-י-ם relates to finishing or completing, and 'לְסַיֵּם' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is concluded) with אֶת (et). It can apply to concluding tasks, events, or processes, often with a sense of finality or resolution. Its moderate frequency in both casual and formal contexts, combined with Piel complexity, makes it advanced yet practical, distinct from simpler Piel verbs like 'to repair' (לְתַקֵּן).

idioms.translation: concluded with clean hands (finished cleanly or honorably)
idioms.usage: הוּא סִייֵּם אֶת הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט בְּיָדַיִם נְקִיּוֹת וּבְזֹמַן.

livchon.root_meaning: Related to examining, testing, or evaluating

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי בּוֹחֵן אֶת הַתַּלְמִידִים בְּמִבְחָן מַתֵּמָטִיקָה.
examples.transliteration: Ani bochen et hatalmidim bemivchan matematika.
examples.translation: I am examining the students with a math test.

examples.hebrew: הֵם בָּחֲנוּ אֶת הַמִּזּוֹן לִפְנֵי הַשִּׁימּוּשׁ.
examples.transliteration: Hem bachan et hamizon lifney hashimush.
examples.translation: They examined the food before use.

livchon.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern, but its transitive nature, intellectual depth, and use in testing or evaluating elevate it to advanced. The root ב-ח-ן relates to examining or proving, and 'לִבְחוֹן' requires a direct object (what is examined) with אֶת (et), often implying a deliberate evaluation. Its moderate frequency in educational, technical, or introspective contexts, combined with its nuanced application, makes it advanced yet practical, distinct from basic Qal verbs like 'to write' (לִכְתּוֹב).
similar_verbs: לְבָרֵר (levarer) - to clarify (in a verifying sense)

idioms.usage: הַמְּנַהֵל בָּחַן אֶת הָעוֹבְדִים בְּאֵשׁ לִרְאוֹת מִי יַצְלִיחַ.

le’oded.root_meaning: Related to encouraging, supporting, or strengthening

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְעוֹדֵד אֶת הַיְּלָדִים לִלְמוֹד בְּחֶדְוָה.
examples.transliteration: Ani me’oded et hayeladim lilmud b’chedva.
examples.translation: I am encouraging the children to study with joy.

examples.hebrew: הֵם עוֹדְדוּ אֶת הַצּוֹמֵת לִפְעוֹל בִּמְרִיצוּת.
examples.translation: They encouraged the team to work energetically.

le’oded.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root ע-ו-ד relates to supporting or strengthening, and 'לְעוֹדֵד' is transitive, typically requiring a direct object (whom is encouraged) with אֶת (et), often followed by לְ (le-, 'to') with an infinitive for the action encouraged. Its moderate frequency in supportive or motivational contexts, combined with Piel complexity, makes it advanced yet practical, distinct from simpler Piel verbs like 'to repair' (לְתַקֵּן).

idioms.usage: הַמְּאַמֵּן עוֹדֵד רוּחַ שֶׁל הַשַּׂחְקָנִים לִפְנֵי הַמִּשְׂחָק.

le’atger.root_meaning: Related to challenging, provoking, or stimulating

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְאַתְגֵּר אֶת הַתַּלְמִידִים לְחַשֵּׁב יוֹתֵר.
examples.transliteration: Ani me’atger et hatalmidim lechashev yoter.
examples.translation: I am challenging the students to think more.

examples.hebrew: הֵם אִיתְגְּרוּ אֶת הַיָּרִיב בְּמִשְׂחָק קָשֶׁה.
examples.translation: They challenged the opponent in a tough game.

le’atger.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root א-ת-ג-ר relates to provoking or testing, and 'לְאַתְגֵּר' is transitive, typically requiring a direct object (whom or what is challenged) with אֶת (et), often followed by לְ (le-, 'to') with an infinitive for the action challenged. Its four-letter root, moderate frequency in competitive or motivational contexts, and Piel complexity make it advanced yet practical, distinct from simpler Piel verbs like 'to repair' (לְתַקֵּן).
similar_verbs: לִבְחוֹן (livchon) - to examine (in a testing sense)

idioms.usage: הוּא אִיתְגֵּר אֶת הַגְּבוּל בְּנוֹסֵעַ לְמָקוֹם חָדָשׁ.

le’atger.root_meaning: Related to challenging, provoking, or stimulating

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְאַתְגֵּר אֶת הַתַּלְמִידִים לְחַשֵּׁב יוֹתֵר.
examples.transliteration: Ani me’atger et hatalmidim lechashev yoter.
examples.translation: I am challenging the students to think more.

examples.hebrew: הֵם אִיתְגְּרוּ אֶת הַיָּרִיב בְּמִשְׂחָק קָשֶׁה.
examples.translation: They challenged the opponent in a tough game.

le’atger.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root א-ת-ג-ר relates to provoking or testing, and 'לְאַתְגֵּר' is transitive, typically requiring a direct object (whom or what is challenged) with אֶת (et), often followed by לְ (le-, 'to') with an infinitive for the action challenged. Its four-letter root, moderate frequency in competitive or motivational contexts, and Piel complexity make it advanced yet practical, distinct from simpler Piel verbs like 'to repair' (לְתַקֵּן).
similar_verbs: לִבְחוֹן (livchon) - to examine (in a testing sense)

idioms.usage: הוּא אִיתְגֵּר אֶת הַגְּבוּל בְּנוֹסֵעַ לְמָקוֹם חָדָשׁ.

lenahalmassaumatan.root_meaning: Related to managing, conducting, or leading

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְנַהֵל מַשָּׂא וּמַתָּן עִם הַסַּפָּקִים עַל הַמְּחִירִים.
examples.transliteration: Ani menahel massa umatan im hasapakim al hamechirím.
examples.translation: I am negotiating with the suppliers about the prices.

examples.hebrew: הֵם נִיהֲלוּ מַשָּׂא וּמַתָּן לְמַעַן הַסְכֵּם שָׁלוֹם.
examples.transliteration: Hem nihalu massa umatan lema’an haskem shalom.
examples.translation: They negotiated for a peace agreement.

lenahalmassaumatan.notes: This verb phrase uses 'לְנָהֵל' (to manage) in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל) with the fixed noun 'מַשָּׂא וּמַתָּן' (lit. 'burden and giving,' meaning negotiation) to mean 'to negotiate.' While 'לְנָהֵל' alone is transitive and means 'to manage,' paired with 'מַשָּׂא וּמַתָּן,' it specifically denotes negotiating, often with עִם (im, 'with') for the counterpart or עַל (al, 'about') for the subject. Its multi-word structure, moderate frequency in business or diplomatic contexts, and strategic nuance make it advanced yet practical, distinct from single-root verbs like 'to manage' (לְנָהֵל) alone.
similar_verbs: לְהַגִּיעַ לְהַסְכָּמָה (lehagia le’has’kama) - to reach an agreement
לְדַבֵּר (ledaber) - to speak (in a broader conversational sense)

idioms.usage: הוּא נִיהֵל מַשָּׂא וּמַתָּן בְּחָכְמָה וְזָכָה בְּהֶסְכֵּם טוֹב.

la’asot.root_meaning: Related to doing, making, or acting

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי עוֹשֶׂה אֶת הַשִּׁעוּרִים שֶׁלִּי עַכְשָׁו.
examples.translation: I am doing my homework now.

examples.hebrew: הֵם עָשׂוּ אֶת הַתּוֹכְנִית בְּצוּרָה מֻצְלַחַת.
examples.translation: They did the plan successfully.

la’asot.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern, and is one of the most fundamental and versatile verbs in Hebrew. The root ע-ש-ה relates to doing or making, and 'לַעֲשׂוֹת' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is done) with אֶת (et) when specific, though it can stand alone in general statements (e.g., 'מָה אַתָּה עוֹשֶׂה?' - 'What are you doing?'). Its extremely high frequency across all contexts—daily tasks, creative acts, or general actions—makes it essential, though its simplicity classifies it as beginner-level despite its broad use.

idioms.translation: made a big deal out of it (exaggerated something)
idioms.usage: הוּא עָשָׂה מִזֶּה עִנְיָן רַק כִּי הוּא אִיחֵר בְּחָמֵשׁ דַּקּוֹת.

lakachat.root_meaning: Related to taking, receiving, or seizing

examples.translation: I am taking the book from the table.

examples.hebrew: הֵם לָקְחוּ אֶת הַהַזְּמָנָה לָלֶכֶת לַטִּיּוּל.
examples.transliteration: Hem lakchu et hazmana lalekhet latayul.
examples.translation: They took the opportunity to go on a trip.

lakachat.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern, and is a core, high-frequency verb in Hebrew. The root ל-ק-ח relates to taking or receiving, and 'לָקַחַת' is transitive, typically requiring a direct object (what is taken) with אֶת (et) when specific, though it can be used generally (e.g., 'קַח!' - 'Take!'). Its high frequency in physical (e.g., taking objects) and abstract (e.g., taking time, opportunities) contexts, along with its simplicity, makes it beginner-level yet indispensable in daily speech.

idioms.translation: took it into his own hands (took control)
idioms.usage: הוּא לָקַח אֶת הַזֹּאת בְּיָדַיִם כְּשֶׁרָאָה שֶׁאֵין עֶזְרָה.

lihyot.root_meaning: Related to being, existing, or becoming

present.note: Hebrew does not use 'לִהְיוֹת' in the present tense; existence or identity is implied by pronouns or nouns alone (e.g., 'אֲנִי תַּלְמִיד' - 'I am a student'). The verb appears only in past, future, and infinitive forms.

imperative.note: There is no imperative form for 'לִהְיוֹת' as it denotes a state of being rather than an action that can be commanded.

examples.translation: I want to be a doctor in the future.
They were at home yesterday.

lihyot.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל) and is the primary verb of being in Hebrew, used to express existence, identity, or states (e.g., 'הוּא תַּלְמִיד' - 'He is a student,' implied present tense). Unlike most verbs, it has no present tense form; pronouns or nouns alone suffice (e.g., 'אֲנִי שְׂמֵחָה' - 'I am happy'). Its root ה-י-ה reflects existence, and its high frequency in past (e.g., 'הָיָה') and future (e.g., 'יִהְיֶה') forms, especially in storytelling and planning, makes it foundational. The lack of a present tense and imperative distinguishes it from typical verbs, but its simplicity keeps it beginner-level.
similar_verbs: לִהְיוֹת קַיָּם (lihyot kayam) - to exist (more formal)

idioms.usage: הַמַּצָּב הָיָה וְנִשְׁאַר קָשֶׁה כְּמוֹ שֶׁהָיָה.

lihyotle.root_meaning: Related to being, existing, or becoming

imperative.note: There is no imperative form for 'לִהְיוֹת לְ-' as it denotes possession rather than an action that can be commanded. Possession is expressed with 'יֵשׁ' or other structures.

examples.translation: I have a new book now.
They had a big house in the village.

lihyotle.notes: This verb phrase uses 'לִהְיוֹת' (to be) in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל) with 'לְ-' (le-, 'to') and a pronoun or noun to express possession. In the present, 'יֵשׁ' (yesh, 'there is') with 'לְ-' replaces 'לִהְיוֹת' (e.g., 'יֵשׁ לִי' - 'I have'), while past and future use 'הָיָה' and 'יִהְיֶה' respectively (e.g., 'הָיָה לִי' - 'I had'). It’s transitive in the sense of possessing an object, typically followed by the item possessed. Its extremely high frequency in all tenses for expressing ownership or availability, combined with its simple structure, makes it beginner-level yet foundational in Hebrew.
related_words: מִי שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ (mi sheyesh lo) - whoever has (phrase)

idioms.translation: I have something to rely on (I’m supported)
idioms.usage: יֵשׁ לִי עַל מָה לְהִסְתַּמֵּךְ כִּי הַמִּשְׁפָּחָה תָּמִיד עוֹזֶרֶת.

litz’tarekh.root_meaning: Related to needing, requiring, or lacking

imperative.note: The imperative is rarely used directly for 'לִצְטָרֵךְ' as needing is a state, not a command. Typically, need is expressed indirectly (e.g., 'תִּקַּח מָה שֶׁצָּרִיךְ' - 'Take what you need').

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי צָרִיךְ לָלֶכֶת לְבֵית הַסֵּפֶר עַכְשָׁו.
examples.translation: I need to go to school now.

examples.hebrew: הֵם צָרְכוּ אֶת הָעֶזְרָה שֶׁלְּךָ אֶתְמוֹל.
examples.transliteration: Hem tzar’khu et ha’ezra shelcha etmol.
examples.translation: They needed your help yesterday.

litz’tarekh.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern, and is a staple for expressing necessity in Hebrew. The root צ-ר-ך relates to need or requirement, and 'לִצְטָרֵךְ' can be transitive with a direct object (what is needed) using אֶת (et) or followed by לְ (le-, 'to') with an infinitive for what must be done. Its extremely high frequency in daily speech—covering personal needs, obligations, or lacks—makes it beginner-level and essential, though the imperative is rarely used directly due to its stative nature.
similar_verbs: לָדַעַת (lada’at) - to know (in a knowledge-need sense)

idioms.usage: בַּדֶּרֶךְ הַזֹּו צָרִיךְ לְהִזָּהֵר מִפְּנֵי הַסַּכָּנוֹת.

latzet.root_meaning: Related to going out, exiting, or departing

examples.translation: I am going out of the house now.
They went out for a trip in the morning.

latzet.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern, and is a core verb for movement in Hebrew. The root י-צ-א relates to exiting or departing, and 'לָצֵאת' is often intransitive but frequently pairs with prepositions like מִן (min, 'from') to indicate the source or לְ (le-, 'to') for the destination. Its extremely high frequency in daily speech—covering physical exits, social outings, or figurative departures (e.g., 'going out of business')—makes it beginner-level and indispensable, with a short, commonly used imperative (e.g., 'צֵא!' - 'Go out!').

idioms.translation: went out of his mind (lost control)
idioms.usage: הוּא יָצָא מִדַּעְתּוֹ כְּשֶׁשָּׁמַע אֶת הַבְּשׂוֹרָה.

lasim.root_meaning: Related to putting, placing, or setting

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי שָׂם אֶת הַסֵּפֶר עַל הַשֻּׁלְחָן.
examples.translation: I am putting the book on the table.

examples.hebrew: הֵם שָׂמוּ אֶת הַכֹּל בַּמָּקוֹם הַנָּכוֹן.
examples.transliteration: Hem samu et hakol bamakom hanakhon.
examples.translation: They put everything in the right place.

lasim.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern, and is a core verb for placement in Hebrew. The root ש-י-ם relates to putting or setting, and 'לָשִׂים' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is put) with אֶת (et), often paired with prepositions like עַל (’al, 'on') or בְּ (be-, 'in') to indicate location. Its extremely high frequency in daily speech—covering physical placement, setting conditions, or assigning value (e.g., 'לָשִׂים לֵב' - 'to pay attention')—makes it beginner-level and essential, with a short, commonly used imperative (e.g., 'שִׂים!' - 'Put!').

idioms.usage: הוּא שָׂם לֵב לְכָל פְּרָט בַּשִּׂיחָה.

lekabel.root_meaning: Related to receiving, accepting, or obtaining

examples.translation: I am getting the gift from a friend.
They got the decision with joy.

lekabel.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root ק-ב-ל relates to receiving or accepting, and 'לְקַבֵּל' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is received) with אֶת (et), often paired with מִן (min, 'from') to indicate the source. Its extremely high frequency in daily speech—covering physical receipt (e.g., gifts), abstract gains (e.g., decisions), or acceptance—makes it beginner-level despite the Piel form, with a commonly used imperative (e.g., 'קַבֵּל!' - 'Get!').
similar_verbs: לִשְׁמוֹעַ (lishmo’a) - to hear (in an information-receiving sense)

idioms.usage: הוּא קִיבֵּל עַל עַצְמוֹ לְתַקֵּן אֶת הַכֹּל בַּבַּיִת.

meaning: to be accepted (e.g., into a job/school)

lekabel.root_meaning: Related to receiving, accepting, or obtaining

examples.translation: I am getting the gift from a friend.
They got the decision with joy.

lekabel.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root ק-ב-ל relates to receiving or accepting, and 'לְקַבֵּל' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is received) with אֶת (et), often paired with מִן (min, 'from') to indicate the source. Its extremely high frequency in daily speech—covering physical receipt (e.g., gifts), abstract gains (e.g., decisions), or acceptance—makes it beginner-level despite the Piel form, with a commonly used imperative (e.g., 'קַבֵּל!' - 'Get!').
similar_verbs: לִשְׁמוֹעַ (lishmo’a) - to hear (in an information-receiving sense)

idioms.usage: הוּא קִיבֵּל עַל עַצְמוֹ לְתַקֵּן אֶת הַכֹּל בַּבַּיִת.

meaning: to be accepted (e.g., into a job/school)

lekabel.root_meaning: Related to receiving, accepting, or obtaining

examples.translation: I am getting the gift from a friend.
They got the decision with joy.

lekabel.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or transitive actions. The root ק-ב-ל relates to receiving or accepting, and 'לְקַבֵּל' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is received) with אֶת (et), often paired with מִן (min, 'from') to indicate the source. Its extremely high frequency in daily speech—covering physical receipt (e.g., gifts), abstract gains (e.g., decisions), or acceptance—makes it beginner-level despite the Piel form, with a commonly used imperative (e.g., 'קַבֵּל!' - 'Get!').
similar_verbs: לִשְׁמוֹעַ (lishmo’a) - to hear (in an information-receiving sense)

idioms.usage: הוּא קִיבֵּל עַל עַצְמוֹ לְתַקֵּן אֶת הַכֹּל בַּבַּיִת.

meaning: to be accepted (e.g., into a job/school)

limtzo.root_meaning: Related to finding, discovering, or encountering

examples.translation: I am finding the key in the bag.
They found a solution to the problem.

limtzo.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern, and is a fundamental verb for discovery in Hebrew. The root מ-צ-א relates to finding or encountering, and 'לִמְצוֹא' is transitive, typically requiring a direct object (what is found) with אֶת (et), often paired with prepositions like בְּ (be-, 'in') or לְ (le-, 'to') for location or purpose. Its extremely high frequency in daily speech—covering physical finds (e.g., objects), abstract discoveries (e.g., solutions), or chance encounters—makes it beginner-level and essential, with a commonly used imperative (e.g., 'מְצָא!' - 'Find!').
similar_verbs: לִרְאוֹת (lir’ot) - to see (in a noticing sense)

idioms.usage: אַחֲרֵי הַטִּיּוּל הוּא מָצָא אֶת עַצְמוֹ כְּאָדָם חָדָשׁ.

lehistakel.root_meaning: Related to looking, observing, or considering

examples.translation: I am looking at the beautiful scenery.
They looked at the pictures with joy.

lehistakel.notes: This verb is in the Hitpael binyan (הִתְפָּעֵל), typically reflexive or reciprocal, but here it functions as a common transitive verb meaning 'to look at' with attention. The root ס-כ-ל relates to observing or considering, and 'לְהִסְתַּכֵּל' usually takes a preposition like עַל (’al, 'at') or בְּ (be-, 'at/in') followed by the object of observation (without אֶת, unlike direct objects). Its extremely high frequency in daily speech—used for casual observation, focused looking, or contemplation—makes it beginner-level despite the Hitpael form, with a frequently used imperative (e.g., 'הִסְתַּכֵּל!' - 'Look!').

idioms.usage: הִיא הִסְתַּכְּלָה בַּמַּרְאָה וְחָשְׁבָה עַל הַחַיִּים.

lichyot.root_meaning: Related to living, existing, or being alive

examples.translation: I am living in Tel Aviv now.
They lived happy lives in the village.

lichyot.notes: This verb is in the Qal binyan (פָּעַל), the simplest verb pattern, and is a fundamental verb for existence in Hebrew.
